quotes.quote: Liars when they speak the truth are not believed.
quotes.author: Aristotle

quotes.quote: Sometimes the lies you tell are less frightening than the loneliness you might feel if you stopped telling them.
quotes.author: Clare Booth Luce

quotes.quote: Lying increases the creative faculties, expands the ego, and lessens the frictions of social contacts.
quotes.author: Franklin D. Roosevelt

quotes.quote: Repetition does not transform a lie into a truth.
quotes.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quotes.quote: The visionary lies to himself, the liar only to others.
quotes.author: H. L. Mencken

quotes.quote: All men are frauds. The only difference between them is that some admit it. I myself deny it.
quotes.author: Jerome K. Jerome

quotes.quote: It is always the best policy to speak the truth--unless, of course, you are an exceptionally good liar.
quotes.author: Lenin

quotes.quote: A lie told often enough becomes the truth.
quotes.author: Mark Twain

quotes.quote: A lie can travel halfway around the world while the truth is putting on its shoes.
quotes.author: Mark Twain

quotes.quote: The history of our race, and each individual's experience, are sown thick with evidence that a truth is not hard to kill and that a lie told well is immortal.
quotes.author: Plato

quotes.quote: Lies are like children: they're hard work, but it's worth it because the future depends on them.
quotes.author: Quintilian

quotes.quote: False words are not only evil in themselves, but they infect the soul with evil.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.quote: A liar should have a good memory.
quotes.author: Sallust

quotes.quote: Truth is beautiful, without doubt; but so are lies.
quotes.author: Samuel Butler

quotes.quote: Ambition drove many men to become false; to have one thought locked in the breast, another ready on the tongue.
quotes.author: Samuel Butler

quotes.quote: Any fool can tell the truth, but it requires a man of some sense to know how to lie well.
quotes.author: Sir Walter Scott

quotes.quote: The best liar is he who makes the smallest amount of lying go the longest way.
quotes.author: Sophocles

quotes.quote:
Oh what a tangled web we weave,
When first we practise to deceive!

Truly, to tell lies is not honorable;
but when the truth entails tremendous ruin,
To speak dishonorably is pardonable.
